content: A link can be created to share code written on the lean4 web , but it is too long. Can it be simplified to a shorter link?
Too long for what? There's general purpose URL shorteners you can find on the web

That's generally not a bad idea, one could potentially compress the #code= part of the URL. However, I'm not sure about the right algorithm for this. I just tried lz-string but it made typical examples from Zulip rather longer than shorter (compression rate ~0.7 after URI-encoding), or didn't yield a valid string that could be URI-encoded at all...
In Lean3 we solved this by being able to point the editor at a url, and then hosting the file somewhere on github
Why do you need short urls anyway?

Eric Wieser said:

In Lean3 we solved this by being able to point the editor at a url, and then hosting the file somewhere on github

That option exists ("Load from URL" in the menu):
https://lean.math.hhu.de/#url=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fhhu-adam%2FNNG4%2Fmain%2FGame%2FTactic%2FRfl.lean
(which loads this random file from github)

Why do you need short urls anyway?

Lean4 web is useful for sharing short code snippets in lean4. However, there are some problems when URLs are too long.
For example, it may get caught by the character limit of social networking services.

There's general purpose URL shorteners you can find on the web

https://t.ly/ is useful for shortening URLs and I currently use it. However, some people are unaware of the existence of such services.
Maybe one can look at Compiler Explorer (godbolt.org) for inspiration? It has shortened links automatically.
I think they just store the data on their server in a hash-table, like t.ly or any other general-purpose tool mentioned above
Asei Inoue has marked this topic as resolved.
